questions.text:
A physiologist is studying blood flow in a network of four parallel blood vessels. The effective resistance of the network of vessels is 4.8 R units. The pressure at the proximal end of the network is 150 mmHg, and the pressure at the distal end is 90 mmHg.

What is the total blood flow rate through the network of vessels?

choices.text: 8 L/s
20 L/s

questions.solution:
Explanation:

Effective Perfusion Pressure = 150 mmHg ‚àí 90 mmHg= 60 mmHg

Using the blood flow analogue of Ohm's law,

ùëÖ total = 4.8R units

Flow = Pressure / Resistance

= 60/4.8 =12.5 L/s

¬†

Factors Influencing Blood Flow within vessels:

  • Pressure differences
  • Resistance

Flow, Pressure, and Resistance Relationship: Blood Flow Analog of Ohm‚Äôs law: Blood flow (F) in any part of the circulatory system is determined by the effective perfusion pressure (P) and the resistance (R) it encounters: F = P/R

  • The Poiseuille-Hagen formula describes the relationship between flow in a narrow tube, fluid viscosity, and tube radius. This formula is represented as:

¬†

Where:

  • F = flow
  • PA ‚àí PB = pressure difference between the tube's two ends
  • Œ∑ = viscosity
  • r = tube radius
  • L = tube length

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Capillaries provide maximum total peripheral resistance
Arteries contain the most blood volume in the systemic circulation
Fenestrated capillaries has gaps size ranging from 300-600 nm
A-V anastomoses found in earlobes have thick, muscular walls

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) A-V anastomoses found in earlobes have thick, muscular walls

¬†

Explanation:

Arteriovenous anastomoses (A-V anastomoses), also known as shunts, are direct connections between arterioles and venules that bypass the capillary bed. They have thick, muscular walls and are abundantly innervated, likely by vasoconstrictor nerve fibers. These shunts are found in the fingers, palms, and earlobes.


¬†

Other types of Blood vessels:

¬†

Blood Vessel Type

Blood Volume

Arteries

  • Carry oxygenated blood away from the heart.
  • Arteries have elastic tissue in their walls, allowing them to stretch and recoil with the pumping of the heart.

8%

Arterioles

  • They are the primary site of resistance to blood flow
  • Contain a high proportion of smooth muscle

1%

Capillaries

  • Tiny vessels with thin walls for the exchange of gases, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissues.

5%

Veins

  • Veins have thinner walls allowing them to distend easily and accommodate larger volumes of blood.
  • Contain venous valves to prevent backflow of blood

54% (Option B)


¬†

Types of capillaries:

¬†


¬†

Capillaries, due to their large cross-sectional area, provide low resistance to blood flow. The arterioles actually provide the maximum total peripheral resistance (Option A)

¬†

Veins, not arteries, contain the most blood volume in the systemic circulation (Option B)

¬†

The typical pore size in fenestrated capillaries is around 60-80 nm(Option C)

¬†

¬†

¬†

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the characteristics of laminar blood flow?

choices.text: Laminar blood flow is characterized by chaotic and irregular movements with significant mixing of fluid layers.
Laminar blood flow occurs at high velocities and low fluid viscosity, leading to smooth and orderly movement.
Laminar blood flow occurs at low velocities and high fluid viscosity, with fluid particles moving in parallel layers.
Laminar blood flow is responsible for generating Korotkoff sounds during blood pressure measurement.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Laminar blood flow occurs at low velocities and high fluid viscosity, with fluid particles moving in parallel layers.

¬†

Explanation:

Laminar blood flow is where the fluid moves in smooth, parallel layers with minimal mixing, typically occurring at low velocities and high viscosity.

Laminar Flow

  • Smooth, orderly flow of fluid in parallel layers with no disruption between the layers.
  • Characteristics:
    • Fluid particles move in straight, parallel paths.
    • Velocity of fluid is highest at the center and decreases towards the vessel walls.
    • Occurs at lower velocities and with lower fluid density or higher fluid viscosity (Option B).

Turbulent Flow

  • Chaotic, irregular flow where fluid particles move in various directions, often forming eddies.
  • Characteristics:
    • Disorganized movement with mixing of fluid layers (Option A).
    • Velocity varies unpredictably at any point in the fluid.
    • Higher resistance compared to laminar flow.
    • Occurs at higher velocities, with higher fluid density, or lower fluid viscosity.

Reynolds Number (Re)

  • Dimensionless numbers used to predict flow patterns in fluid dynamics.
  • Interpretation:
    • Re < 2000: Flow is typically laminar.
    • Re > 4000: Flow is typically turbulent.
    • Re 2000-4000: Transitional flow, where both laminar and turbulent flow may exist.

Korotkoff Sounds

  • Sounds heard while measuring blood pressure using a sphygmomanometer and stethoscope.
  • Mechanism:
    • Created by turbulent blood flow in the brachial artery when external pressure is between systolic and diastolic pressures.
    • As cuff pressure drops below systolic pressure, blood begins to flow turbulently (Option D), producing Korotkoff sounds.
    • When cuff pressure drops below diastolic pressure, laminar flow is restored, and sounds disappear.

¬†

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly applies the law of Laplace in cardiovascular physiology?

choices.text: Capillaries are prone to rupture due to high wall tension.
Dilated hearts have to work harder due to increased myocardial tension.
Increased flow velocity in narrow vessels reduces distending pressure.
The total energy in a tube or blood vessel remains constant.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Dilated hearts have to work harder due to increased myocardial tension.

¬†

Explanation:

According to the law of Laplace, dilated hearts require greater myocardial tension to produce a given pressure, increasing cardiac workload.

¬†

Principle

Definition

Applications

Law of Laplace

The tension in the wall of a cylinder is equal to the product of transmural pressure and radius divided by wall thickness.

T= P.r/ 2w ( T= Tension, P= Transmural pressure, r= Radius, w= Wall thickness)

Capillaries: Low tension in walls due to small radius, resistant to rupture. (Option A)

Dilated Hearts: Increased radius requires more tension, increasing cardiac workload.(Option B)

Bernoulli Principle

The total energy in a tube or blood vessel (kinetic energy + potential energy) remains constant. (Option D)


¬†

Pressure Measurement: Lower side arm pressure in a T tube due to kinetic energy of flow. Atherosclerotic Plaques: Increased flow velocity in narrow vessels reduces distending pressure, maintaining vessel narrowing. (Option C)

¬†

questions.text: A 45-y/o male patient presents with a blood pressure reading of 150/90 mmHg. Which of the following statements about his pulse pressure (PP) and mean arterial pressure (MAP) is correct?

choices.text: Pulse pressure is 40 mmHg, and MAP is 110 mmHg.
Pulse pressure is 60 mmHg, and MAP is 100 mmHg.
Pulse pressure is 60 mmHg, and MAP is 110 mmHg.
Pulse pressure is 40 mmHg, and MAP is 100 mmHg.

questions.solution:
¬†

Correct Answer: C) Pulse pressure is 60 mmHg, and MAP is 110 mmHg.

¬†

Explanation:

Pulse Pressure (PP): Pulse pressure is calculated as the difference between systolic blood pressure (SBP) and diastolic blood pressure (DBP).
PP= SBP‚àíDBP= 150‚àí90= 60 mmHg

Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP): Mean arterial pressure is calculated using the formula:
MAP= DBP+1/3(SBP‚àíDBP)= 90+1/3(150‚àí90)=90+20= 110 mmHg

¬†

Feature

Pulse Pressure (PP)

Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP)

Definition

Difference between systolic and diastolic blood pressure

Average pressure in arteries during one cardiac cycle

Calculation

PP=SBP‚àíDBP

MAP=DBP+1/3(SBP‚àíDBP)

Normal Range

40-60 mmHg

70-100 mmHg

Clinical Significance

Indicates cardiovascular health and heart function

A better indicator of perfusion to vital organs

Implications of High Values

Risk of cardiovascular events

Can indicate a risk of hypertension and organ damage

Implications of Low Values

This may suggest poor heart function

This may indicate poor perfusion of vital organs

questions.text: Which of the following is the fastest acting method of BP regulation?

choices.text: Capillary fluid shift
Baroreceptor reflex
Renin-angiotensin vasoconstriction
Renal body fluid mechanism

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Baroreceptor reflex

¬†

Explanation:

1. Methods of BP Regulation

Time Frame

Mechanisms

Functions

Short-term (seconds to minutes)
  • Autonomic nervous system
  • Baroreceptor reflex
  • Central nervous system ischemic response
  • Chemoreceptor mechanism
  • Constrict veins to increase blood flow to the heart
  • Increase heart rate and contractility
  • Constrict peripheral arterioles to elevate BP

Intermediate-term (minutes to hours)
  • Angiotensin mediated vasoconstriction (Option C)
  • Stress relaxation
  • Capillary fluid shift (Option A)
  • Renin triggers angiotensin II, constricting blood vessels and increasing BP
  • Sustained high BP leads to gradual pressure reduction
  • Fluid absorption or loss in capillaries adjusts blood volume and BP

Long-term (days to years)
  • Renal-body fluid mechanism (Option D)
  • Aldosterone influence
  • Regulate salt and water excretion to maintain BP stability
  • Aldosterone promotes salt and water retention when BP is low

2. Baroreceptor Reflex

Aspect

Details

Mechanism
  • Baroreceptors in carotid sinus and aortic arch detect BP changes
  • Increased BP stretches receptors, sending signals to medulla via glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves
  • Medulla inhibits vasoconstrictor center and stimulates vagal parasympathetic center

Actions
  • Vasodilation of blood vessels
  • Decreased heart rate and contraction strength
  • Reduced BP due to lower peripheral resistance and cardiac output

Importance
  • Maintains BP stability during activities like standing
  • Fastest acting (Option B)
  • Tends to reset within 1-2 days for long-term regulation

¬†

questions.text: A patient undergoing PCI for myocardial infarction suddenly develops bradycardia, hypotension, and episodes of apnoea.Which of the following reflexes is most likely mediated by chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region?

choices.text: Cushing reflex
Bainbridge reflex
Bezold-Jarisch reflex
Baroreceptor reflex

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bezold-Jarisch reflex

¬†

Explanation:

Myocardial ischemia and reperfusion activates chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region causing Bezold‚ÄìJarisch reflex leading to profound bradycardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing.

¬†

Bezold-Jarisch reflex or coronary chemoreflex:

  • Activators: Capsaicin, serotonin, phenylbiguanide, veratridine and pathophysiologic conditions like reperfusion after myocardial ischemia ( increased production of oxygen radicals and agents used as radio contrast for coronary angiography).
  • Mechanism: Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers (Option C) in the cardiopulmonary region (juxtacapillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery).
  • Causing bradycardia, hypotension, and a brief apnea period followed by rapid shallow breathing.


¬†

Cushing reflex (Option A): A combination of hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration is known as the triad of the Cushing reflex.

Bainbridge reflex(Option B): Following vagotomy, the reflex is abolished as the responses are mediated by vagus nerves shown below.

Baroreceptor reflex (Option D) or sino-aortic reflex: It quickly adjusts heart rate and vascular tone in response to changes in blood pressure to maintain cardiovascular stability.

¬†

¬†

questions.text: A patient with massive blood loss is found to have increased sympathetic nervous system activity, resulting in elevated blood pressure. Which combination of factors primarily triggers the central nervous system (CNS) ischemic response?

choices.text: Hypoxia and hypercapnia
Hypoxia and hypocapnia
Hypoglycemia and hypoxia
Hypoglycemia and hypercapnia

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hypoxia and hypercapnia

¬†

Explanation:

Decreased blood flow due to massive hemorrhage here causes significant drop in blood pressure leading to severe hypoxia and hypercapnia which activates Vasomotor center, increasing blood pressure and restoring cerebral perfusion.

¬†

CNS ischemic response:

  • Vasomotor center (VMC) is very sensitive to local hypoxia and local hypercapnia causing strong sympathetic system activation as follows. (Option A)
  • Failure of this response leads to irreversible shock as this is the last physiological reflex to correct blood pressure.

¬†

Hypoglycemia does not trigger the central nervous system (CNS) ischemic response.

¬†

Hypoxia and hypocapnia (Option B): Hypocapnia (low CO‚ÇÇ) causes vasoconstriction in the brain, which would reduce cerebral blood flow, not stimulate it. This combo is not a trigger for the CNS ischemic response.

Hypoglycemia and hypoxia¬† (Option C): Although hypoglycemia affects brain function, it does not primarily trigger the CNS ischemic reflex. This reflex is about perfusion pressure, not glucose levels.

Hypoglycemia and hypercapnia¬† (Option D): Again, hypoglycemia isn‚Äôt the key trigger. While hypercapnia is part of the correct answer, pairing it with hypoglycemia misses the critical ischemic signal: low oxygen from low perfusion.

¬†

questions.text: 55-y/o patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with acute exacerbation. ABG shows severe hypoxemia and hypercapnia. How do peripheral chemoreceptors respond to these changes, and its effect on blood pressure?

choices.text: Stimulation of chemoreceptors leading to hypertension
Deactivation of chemoreceptors leading to hypotension
No response of chemoreceptors leading to hypotension
Deactivation of chemoreceptors but no response on blood pressure

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Stimulation of chemoreceptors leading to hypertension

¬†

Explanation:

In the scenario, severe hypoxemia and hypercapnia stimulate peripheral chemoreceptors and afferent signals stimulate cardio inhibitory center (CIC) to produce bradycardia and vasomotor center (VMC) to produce vasoconstriction as a part of the primary effect.

¬†

Chemoreceptor reflex and BP:

¬†

¬†

  • Afferent from the carotid body: IX cranial nerve
  • Afferent from aortic body: X cranial nerve

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with acute exacerbation. ABG shows severe hypoxemia and hypercapnia. How do peripheral chemoreceptors respond to these changes, and its effect on blood pressure?

choices.text: Stimulation of chemoreceptors leading to hypertension
Deactivation of chemoreceptors leading to hypotension
No response of chemoreceptors leading to hypotension
Deactivation of chemoreceptors but no response on blood pressure

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Stimulation of chemoreceptors leading to hypertension

¬†

Explanation:

¬†

In the scenario, severe hypoxemia and hypercapnia, stimulates peripheral chemoreceptors and afferent signals stimulate cardio inhibitory center (CIC) to produce bradycardia and vasomotor center (VMC) to produce vasoconstriction as apart of primary effect.

¬†

Chemoreceptor reflex and BP:

¬†

  • Afferent from carotid body: IX cranial nerve
  • Afferent from aortic body: X cranial nerve

Deactivation of chemoreceptors leading to hypotension (Option B)‚Äì Severe hypoxemia and hypercapnia stimulate, not deactivate, chemoreceptors.

No response of chemoreceptors leading to hypotension¬†(Option C) ‚Äì Peripheral chemoreceptors actively respond to hypoxemia by increasing sympathetic output.

Deactivation of chemoreceptors but no response on blood pressure (Option D)‚Äì Chemoreceptors are stimulated, not deactivated, and they influence blood pressure via vasoconstriction.

questions.text: A 55 y/o man is undergoing a treadmill stress test. Which of the following is true about coronary perfusion?

choices.text: Primarily occurs during left ventricle systole
It is the difference between aortic systolic pressure and diastolic pressure.
Right ventricle perfusion decreases during systole than diastole.
Regulation of coronary blood flow involves local metabolites

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Regulation of coronary blood flow involves local metabolites

Explanation:
Regulation of coronary blood flow involves primarily local metabolites like adenosine, hydrogen ions, lactic acid, potassium ions and certain prostaglandins by mechanism known as metabolite mediated vasodilatation.

Coronary perfusion:

¬†

¬†

Key points

Explanation

Coronary circulation

Supplies heart muscles

Major coronary arteries

Left and right coronary arteries

Rate of blood flow in myocardium

250ml/minute

Percentage of blood flow in heart

5% of cardiac output


¬†

  • The right and left coronary arteries originate from the coronary sinuses at the aortic root.
  • These arteries extend along the epicardium, and then branch through the myocardium to form subendocardial plexuses to perfuse the myocardium.
  • Myocardial contraction during systole compresses arterial branches and prevents perfusion.
  • Coronary perfusion occurs during diastole rather than systole from epicardial to endocardial regions.

¬†

Coronary perfusion pressure: (Option B)

  • Coronary Perfusion Pressure (CPP) = Aortic Diastolic Pressure ‚Äì Left Ventricular end-diastolic Pressure (LVEDP).
  • Aortic systolic pressure; 120 mmHg
  • Aortic diastolic pressure: 80 mmHg
  • Blood flow to the left ventricle occurs only during the early stage of diastole (isovolumetric relaxation) (Option A)
  • Blood flow in the right ventricle occurs during systole and diastole. Blood flow increases in systole than in diastole. (Option C)


¬†

Regulation of coronary perfusion:

¬†

Chemical Factors:

  • Regulation of blood flow occurs primarily through vasodilation caused by local metabolites (Option D) which are formed due to 70-80% oxygen extraction of myocardium from the coronary arteries.
  • Metabolites are CO2 , H+, K+, lactate, prostaglandins, adenine nucleotides, and adenosine.

¬†

Neural factors:

  • Œ±-adrenergic receptors on coronary arterioles: vasoconstriction
  • Œ≤-adrenergic receptors on coronary arterioles: vasodilation

¬†

questions.text: Which of the following statements about myocardial muscle tension is correct?

choices.text: Preload primarily affects the velocity of muscle shortening
Afterload does not affect the duration of systole
Increasing preload leads to decreased muscle tension
The force-velocity relationship in cardiac muscle is inverse and hyperbolic

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) The force-velocity relationship in cardiac muscle is inverse and hyperbolic

Explanation:
The force-velocity relationship in cardiac muscle is inverse and hyperbolic. This fundamental property of cardiac muscle mechanics describes how the velocity of muscle shortening is related to the force (or tension) developed by the muscle.

  • As the load (force) against which the muscle contracts increases, the velocity of shortening decreases.
  • When the muscle contracts against a lighter load, it can shorten more quickly.
  • This relationship is not linear but follows a hyperbolic curve.
  • At zero load, the muscle shortens at its maximum velocity (Vmax), while at maximum isometric force, the shortening velocity is zero.
  • This is how the heart can maintain adequate cardiac output over a wide range of afterloads by adjusting its contractile properties.

Preload primarily affects the force of contraction, not the velocity of muscle shortening. This is based on the Frank-Starling mechanism (Option A)

Afterload does affect the duration of systole. Increased afterload can prolong the duration of systole as the ventricle requires more time to generate sufficient pressure to open the aortic valve and eject blood (Option B)

More EDV( which is the best determinant of preload) leads to increased tension in the cardiac muscle. ‚Üë EDV‚Üí ‚Üë ventricular muscle length ‚Üí ‚Üë muscle contraction force (contractility of the heart). This is known as the Frank-Starling law of the heart (Option C)

¬†

¬†

¬†

questions.text: According to the Monro-Kellie doctrine, which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the intracranial pressure (ICP) homeostasis?

choices.text: An increase in cerebrospinal fluid volume can be compensated by a decrease in brain tissue volume
An increase in blood volume can be offset by a decrease in cerebrospinal fluid volume
The sum of volumes of brain tissue, blood, and cerebrospinal fluid remains constant
A significant increase in one intracranial component always leads to a proportional increase in ICP

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) An increase in cerebrospinal fluid volume can be compensated by a decrease in brain tissue volume

Explanation:

The Monro-Kellie doctrine states that the cranial compartment is incompressible, and the volume inside the cranium is fixed hence Option A in the incorrect statement.The doctrine describes the relationship between the volumes of brain tissue, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), and blood within the cranium.

¬†

¬†

  • According to this principle, an increase in one component must be offset by a decrease in one or both of the other components to maintain a constant intracranial pressure.
  • Brain tissue is not easily compressible, and its volume does not acutely decrease to compensate for increases in other components.
  • Therefore, compensatory mechanisms primarily involve changes in CSF and blood volumes.
    • During a rise in intracranial pressure, CSF can be displaced into the spinal subarachnoid space or its production can be reduced, and/ or venous blood can be displaced from the cranial cavity.

¬†

¬†

An increase in blood volume can be compensated by a decrease in CSF volume (Option B)

¬†

The Principle of the Monro-Kellie doctrine is that the sum of the volumes of brain tissue, blood, and CSF must remain constant within the rigid confines of the skull (Option C)

Small increases in the volume of one component can often be compensated without a significant change in ICP, due to the compensatory mechanisms described earlier. However, once these compensatory mechanisms are exhausted, even small volume increases can lead to dramatic rises in ICP (Option D)

¬†

¬†

¬†

¬†

¬†

questions.text: In a scientific research, large group of non-hypertensive individuals (systolic blood pressures < 120 mm Hg) were studied every 2 years throughout their adult lives. Effects of age and sex on arterial pressure components (systolic and diastolic BP) in the study are given below. Fall of diastolic pressure after the middle age is due to:

choices.text: Increase stiffness of arteries
Decreases stiffness of arteries
Decrease in contractile force of heart
Decrease in total peripheral resistance

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Increase stiffness of arteries

¬†

Explanation:

Fall of diastolic pressure after the middle age is due to increase in stiffness of arteries

Blood Pressure Changes with Age:

  • Systolic Pressure: Increases steadily throughout life, even in individuals with normal initial levels (<120 mm Hg at ages 50‚Äì60).
  • Diastolic Pressure: Rises with age but starts to decline in middle age due to increased arterial stiffness.
  • Pulse Pressure: Increases as the gap between systolic and diastolic pressure widens.
  • Gender Differences: Women have lower blood pressures than men until around ages 55‚Äì65. This may contribute to their longer lifespan, as lower blood pressure is linked to a reduced risk of heart attacks and strokes.

Decrease in Stiffness of Arteries (Option B): Aging typically increases arterial stiffness.

Decrease in Contractile Force of Heart (Option C): Diastolic pressure changes are more related to arterial stiffness than heart contractility.

Decrease in Total Peripheral Resistance (Option D): Aging often increases peripheral resistance, not decreases it.
